articles.headline: America’s Truckers Face a Chronic Headache: Finding Parking
articles.snippet: Parking spots for trucks are in short supply around the country, and the problem can lead to unsafe situations for long-haul truck drivers and other motorists.
articles.abstract: Parking spots for trucks are in short supply around the country, and the problem can lead to unsafe situations for long-haul truck drivers and other motorists.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the wee hours one night in July, a Greyhound bus heading to St. Louis turned onto an exit ramp leading to a rest area in Southern Illinois and hit three parked tractor-trailers, smashing its front, crumpling its roof and ripping off part of its side.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Case on Trump’s Immunity Defense for Now
articles.snippet: The case will instead first be heard by a federal appeals court, which has put it on a fast track, scheduling arguments for Jan. 9.
articles.abstract: The case will instead first be heard by a federal appeals court, which has put it on a fast track, scheduling arguments for Jan. 9.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court declined on Friday to decide for now whether former President Donald J. Trump is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.

articles.headline: A World Leader on Ukraine, the U.S. Is Now Isolated Over Gaza
articles.snippet: The United States finds itself in a defensive crouch and at odds with even staunch allies like France, Canada, Australia and Japan.
articles.abstract: The United States finds itself in a defensive crouch and at odds with even staunch allies like France, Canada, Australia and Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Days of intense negotiations enabled the Biden administration to avoid casting a veto at the United Nations Security Council in defense of Israel’s military campaign in Gaza.

articles.headline: U.N. Passes Resolution on Gaza Aid but Does Not Call for ‘Suspension of Hostilities’
articles.snippet: After a week of heated negotiations, the U.N. Security Council approved a measure that called on Israel and Hamas to pause the fighting to allow for the delivery of more humanitarian aid.
articles.abstract: After a week of heated negotiations, the U.N. Security Council approved a measure that called on Israel and Hamas to pause the fighting to allow for the delivery of more humanitarian aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council on Friday adopted a resolution that would allow more aid to reach desperate civilians in the Gaza Strip, ending nearly a week of intense diplomatic wrangling intended to prevent the United States from blocking the measure. But the resolution stopped short of past attempts to impose a cease-fire.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: How a Crisis in Truck Driving Could Change Life in Japan
articles.snippet: The country is moving to curb the industry’s punishing work hours. But that could leave a shortfall that disrupts Japan’s entire logistics system.
articles.abstract: The country is moving to curb the industry’s punishing work hours. But that could leave a shortfall that disrupts Japan’s entire logistics system.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was dark when Daiki Funamizu pulled his truck into the market in Osaka, ending a 15-hour haul down Japan’s main island. He rubbed his sore back and wiped the sweat off his forehead. Then he began several more hours of work to unload 500 boxes of red apples.
articles.byline: By Hisako Ueno, John Yoon and Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times

articles.headline: Slow Rollout of National Charging System Could Hinder E.V. Adoption
articles.snippet: Lawmakers approved $5 billion for states to build a network of fast chargers two years ago. Although some states have made progress in recent weeks, most have not yet awarded contracts or started construction.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers approved $5 billion for states to build a network of fast chargers two years ago. Although some states have made progress in recent weeks, most have not yet awarded contracts or started construction.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than two years ago, lawmakers approved billions of dollars to build out a national electric vehicle charging network in the hopes of encouraging more drivers to switch to cleaner cars. The money, included in the bipartisan infrastructure law, was intended to help assure drivers they could reliably travel longer distances without running out of power.

articles.headline: Putin Quietly Signals He Is Open to a Cease-Fire in Ukraine
articles.snippet: Despite its bravado in public, the Kremlin has indicated its interest in striking a deal to halt the war — so long as it could still declare victory.
articles.abstract: Despite its bravado in public, the Kremlin has indicated its interest in striking a deal to halt the war — so long as it could still declare victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin’s confidence seems to know no bounds.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski, Adam Entous and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: ‘God Is Under the Rubble in Gaza’: Bethlehem’s Subdued Christmas
articles.snippet: The war in Gaza has prompted the city, traditionally seen as the birthplace of Jesus, to tone down its Christmas celebrations.
articles.abstract: The war in Gaza has prompted the city, traditionally seen as the birthplace of Jesus, to tone down its Christmas celebrations.
articles.lead_paragraph: There will be no musical festivities. No tree-lighting ceremony. No extravagant decorations that normally bedeck the West Bank city of Bethlehem at Christmas. With the war in Gaza raging, this is a city in mourning.
articles.byline: By Yara Bayoumy and Samar Hazboun

articles.headline: Clarence Thomas’s Clerks: An ‘Extended Family’ With Reach and Power
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court justice has built a network of former clerks who share messages, meals and a common vision — wielding influence at universities, law firms and the highest rungs of government.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court justice has built a network of former clerks who share messages, meals and a common vision — wielding influence at universities, law firms and the highest rungs of government.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late August, amid a rising outcry over revelations that Justice Clarence Thomas had received decades of undisclosed gifts and free luxury travel, a lawyer in Chicago fired off an email to her fellow former Thomas clerks.
articles.byline: By Abbie VanSickle and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Two Wars, 50 Elections: The Economy Faces Rising Geopolitical Risks
articles.snippet: Next year could see increasing volatility as persistent military conflicts and economic uncertainty influence voting in national elections across the globe.
articles.abstract: Next year could see increasing volatility as persistent military conflicts and economic uncertainty influence voting in national elections across the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: The attacks on crucial shipping traffic in the Red Sea straits by a determined band of militants in Yemen — a spillover from the Israeli-Hamas war in Gaza — are injecting a new dose of instability into a world economy already struggling with mounting geopolitical tensions.

articles.headline: In Campus Protests Over Gaza, Echoes of Outcry Over Vietnam
articles.snippet: The war in Vietnam ignited a protest movement that helped define a generation. Is the war between Israel and Hamas doing the same thing?
articles.abstract: The war in Vietnam ignited a protest movement that helped define a generation. Is the war between Israel and Hamas doing the same thing?
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard Flacks remembers the challenges of building a protest movement during the Vietnam War as a pillar of the left-wing political and antiwar group Students for a Democratic Society during the 1960s.

articles.headline: What Went Wrong for Ron DeSantis in 2023
articles.snippet: The Florida governor entered the year flush with cash and momentum. In the months since, internal chaos and Donald Trump’s indictments have sapped even his most avid supporters.
articles.abstract: The Florida governor entered the year flush with cash and momentum. In the months since, internal chaos and Donald Trump’s indictments have sapped even his most avid supporters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida woke up in Iowa with a familiar political headache.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Maggie Haberman and Nicholas Nehamas

articles.headline: Christmas Moves to Dec. 25 in Ukraine, Another Rebuff of Russia
articles.snippet: The Ukrainian Orthodox Church formally changed the main date for the festivities, departing from the Russian tradition of celebrating on Jan. 7, according to the Julian calendar.
articles.abstract: The Ukrainian Orthodox Church formally changed the main date for the festivities, departing from the Russian tradition of celebrating on Jan. 7, according to the Julian calendar.
articles.lead_paragraph: Christmas lights flickered on ahead of schedule. Families sang carols a little sooner. And the first presents of the season — by tradition hidden under a pillow or in a boot — appeared two weeks early.

articles.headline: Hoping for Peace With Houthis, Saudis Keep Low Profile in Red Sea Conflict
articles.snippet: Riyadh is seeking to avoid getting dragged back into a bloody clash with the Yemeni militia, which has sowed chaos by attacking shipping and firing missiles at Israel.
articles.abstract: Riyadh is seeking to avoid getting dragged back into a bloody clash with the Yemeni militia, which has sowed chaos by attacking shipping and firing missiles at Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Iran-backed rebels took over the capital of Yemen in 2014, a 30-year-old Saudi prince named Mohammed bin Salman spearheaded a military intervention to rout them.

articles.headline: Mongolians Are Circus Stars All Over the World, Except at Home
articles.snippet: Contortionists and acrobats with celestial skills train in squalid conditions as the promise of a former sumo wrestler to restore the national circus to its past glory has gone mostly unfulfilled.
articles.abstract: Contortionists and acrobats with celestial skills train in squalid conditions as the promise of a former sumo wrestler to restore the national circus to its past glory has gone mostly unfulfilled.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s cold as a walk-in refrigerator at the Mongolian Circus School, housed in a once proud edifice now on the verge of collapse with cracked walls, moldy ceilings and the stale smell of decades of cigarette smoke embedded into the venue’s wooden frame.

articles.headline: The 2023 Good Tech Awards
articles.snippet: Toasting a year of breakthroughs (and a few breakdowns) in Silicon Valley and beyond.
articles.abstract: Toasting a year of breakthroughs (and a few breakdowns) in Silicon Valley and beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the tech industry, 2023 was a year of transformation.

articles.headline: This N.Y.U. Student Owns a $6 Million Crypto Mine. His Secret Is Out.
articles.snippet: A legal dispute in a tiny Texas town unexpectedly reveals how Chinese nationals can move money to the U.S. without drawing the attention of authorities in either country.
articles.abstract: A legal dispute in a tiny Texas town unexpectedly reveals how Chinese nationals can move money to the U.S. without drawing the attention of authorities in either country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jerry Yu has the trappings of what the Chinese call second-generation rich. He boasts a Connecticut prep-school education. He lives in a Manhattan condominium bought for $8 million from Jeffrey R. Immelt, the former General Electric chief executive. And he is the majority owner of a Bitcoin mine in Texas, acquired last year for more than $6 million.
articles.byline: By Michael Forsythe and Gabriel J.X. Dance

articles.headline: 2023 Box Office Lessons: Audiences Sought Comfort, Skipped Spectacle
articles.snippet: Movie audiences flocked to Taylor Swift, “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” but were cooler toward returning superheroes like the Flash, Captain Marvel and Aquaman.
articles.abstract: Movie audiences flocked to Taylor Swift, “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” but were cooler toward returning superheroes like the Flash, Captain Marvel and Aquaman.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hollywood’s movie factories run on conventional wisdom — entrenched notions, based on experience, about what types of films are likely to pop at the global box office.

articles.headline: Netanyahu Visits Gaza as Palestinians Mourn an Attack That Officials Say Killed Dozens
articles.snippet: The Gazan Health Ministry blamed Israeli airstrikes for the deaths, and Israel’s military said it was reviewing the episode.
articles.abstract: The Gazan Health Ministry blamed Israeli airstrikes for the deaths, and Israel’s military said it was reviewing the episode.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited Israeli troops fighting in the Gaza Strip on Monday, vowing to stay the course of the war even with the death toll mounting. His trip came hours after Gazan health officials reported that a devastating overnight strike on a crowded neighborhood had killed dozens.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee, Ameera Harouda, Nadav Gavrielov and Abu Bakr Bashir
